full_article: The only surviving member of the mountaineering expedition that first conquered Mount Everest says the world’s highest peak is too crowded and too dirty and the mountain is a god that needs to be respected. Kanchha Sherpa, now 91, was among the 35 members in the team that put New Zealander Edmund Hillary and his Sherpa guide Tenzing Norgay atop the 8,849-meter (29,032-foot) mountain on May 29, 1953. He said in an interview that it would be better for the mountain if the number of climbers were reduced. There have been concerns about the number of people living on the mountain, generating trash and waste, but authorities have no plans to cut down the number of permits they issue.

title: Cricket records galore as Dutch beat Namibia in Nepal - DutchNews.nl

Brief scores: Netherlands 247-5 (Levitt 135, Engelbrecht 75, Trumpelmann 2-46) beat Namibia 188-7 (Green 42*, Frylinck 42, Van der Gugten 2-26) by 59 runs

Opening batter Michael Levitt bludgeoned his way to an impressive 62-ball 135, the highest individual score by a Dutch batter in T20Is, as the Netherlands cantered to a second victory in as many days by thumping Namibia in the triangular series in Kirtipur (Kathmandu) on Thursday (February 29).

Levitt’s century, only the second by a Dutchman after Max O’Dowd’s 133 against Malaysia at the same venue three years ago, laid the foundation for a mammoth total of 247-5, the highest Dutch total in the format. In reply, the Namibian batters could only manage 188-7.

Playing just his second T20I after making 54 in a narrow 2-run win against hosts Nepal on Wednesday, the 20-year-old Voorburg batter carted eleven fours and ten sixes, scoring 104 runs in boundaries alone, setting another record by a Dutch batter.

At one point, he was batting on 26 off 25 balls before cruising to his century in the next 24 balls.

“That was some of the best striking I have ever seen. It was unbelievable to see from a guy playing just his second game”, captain Scott Edwards said after the game.

After losing Max O’Dowd in the third over, Levitt was involved in a 193-run partnership for the second wicket, the highest-ever for the Netherlands, with his club captain Sybrand Engelbrecht, who slammed a 40-ball 75.

Teja Nidamanuru provided the finishing fireworks, striking three sixes off as many deliveries as left-arm seamer Jan Frylinck gave up 57 runs in his four overs.

Requiring a record chase of 248, Namibia failed to keep up with the run-rate to eventually fall short by 59 runs. Timm van der Gugten picked two wickets while Vivian Kingma continued his impressive tour with another economical outing (1-26).

The Dutch are currently undefeated in the tri-series and will play back-to-back games over the weekend against both the opponents before the final on Tuesday.

All games are live streamed on SportsEye’s YouTube channel.

title: Last surviving member of the first team to conquer Mount Everest says it is crowded and dirty now - The Associated Press
description: Last surviving member of the first team to conquer Mount Everest says it is crowded and dirty now  The Associated Press
publisher.title: The Associated Press
full_article:
KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) — The only surviving member of the mountaineering expedition that first conquered Mount Everest said Saturday that the world’s highest peak is too crowded and dirty, and the mountain is a god that needs to be respected.

Kanchha Sherpa, 91, was among the 35 members in the team that put New Zealander Edmund Hillary and his Sherpa guide Tenzing Norgay atop the 8,849-meter (29,032-foot) peak on May 29, 1953.

“It would be better for the mountain to reduce the number of climbers,” Kanchha said in an interview in Kathmandu on Saturday, “Right now there is always a big crowd of people at the summit.”

Since the first conquest, the peak has been climbed thousands of times, and it gets more crowded every year. During the spring climbing season in 2023, 667 climbers scaled the peak, but that brought in thousands of support staff to the base camp between the months of March and May.

Kanchha Sherpa, right, is helped by his son Tsering Sherpa before an interview with Associated Press at his residence in Kathmandu, Nepal, Saturday, March 2, 2024. (AP Photo/Niranjan Shrestha)

There have been concerns about the number of people living on the mountain for months on end, generating trash and waste, but authorities have no plans to cut down on the number of permits they issue to climbers.

There are rules that require climbers to bring down their own trash, equipment and everything they carry to the mountain or risk losing their deposit, but monitoring has not been very effective.

“It is very dirty now. People throw tins and wrappings after eating food. Who is going to pick them up now?” Kanchha said. “Some climbers just dump their trash in the crevasse, which would be hidden at that time but eventually it will flow down to base camp as the snow melts and carries them downward.”

For the Sherpas, Everest is Qomolangma or goddess mother of the world, and is revered by their community. They generally perform religious rituals before climbing the peak.

Kanchha Sherpa, right, is helped by his son Tsering Sherpa before an interview with Associated Press at his residence in Kathmandu, Nepal, Saturday, March 2, 2024. (AP Photo/Niranjan Shrestha)

“They should not be dirtying the mountain. It is our biggest god and they should not be dirtying the gods,” he said “Qomolangma is the biggest god for the Sherpas but people smoke and eat meat and throw them on the mountain.”

Kanchha was just a young man when he joined the Hillary-Tenzing expedition. He was among the three Sherpas to go to the last camp on Everest along with Hillary and Tenzing. They could not go any further because they did not have a permit.

They first heard of the successful ascent on the radio, and then were reunited with the summit duo at Camp 2.

“We all gathered at Camp 2 but there was no alcohol so we celebrated with tea and snacks,” he said. “We then collected whatever we could and carried it to base camp.”

The route they opened up from the base camp to the summit is still used by climbers. Only the section from the base camp to Camp 1 over the unstable Khumbu Icefall changes every year.

Kanchha has four children, eight grandchildren and a 20-month-old great-granddaughter. He lives with family in Namche village in the foothills of Mount Everest, where the family runs a small hotel catering to trekkers and climbers.
translated: काठमांडू, नेपाल (एपी) — माउंट एवरेस्ट न॑ शनिदिन न॑ शनिवार क॑ कहलकै कि दुनिया केरऽ सबस॑ ऊंचऽ चोटी प॑ बहुत भीड़ आरू गंदा छै, आरू पहाड़ एगो देवता छै, जेकरऽ सम्मान करै के जरूरत छै ।29 मई 1953 क॑ 8,849 मीटर (29,032-फुट) केरऽ शिखर के ऊपर न्यूजीलैंड केरऽ एडमंड हिलेरी आरू हुनकऽ शेर्पा गाइड टेन्ज़िंग नॉर्गय क॑ 29 मई, 1953 क॑ 8,849 मीटर (29,032-फुट) केरऽ चरम प॑ पहुँचाबै वाला टीम केरऽ 35 सदस्यऽ म॑ शामिल कंचा शेर्पा । पर्वतारोही के संख्या कम करै लेली,’ शनिदिन काठमांडू म॑ एगो साक्षात्कार म॑ कंचा न॑ कहलकै, ‘अभी शिखर सम्मेलन म॑ लोगऽ के एगो बड़ऽ भीड़ हमेशा छै ।”पहिल विजय के बाद सं हजारों बेर चरम पर चढ़ल गेल अछि, आ हर साल बेसी भीड़ भ जाइत अछि.2023 म॑ वसंत ऋतु केरऽ क्लाइम्बिंग के मौसम म॑ 667 पर्वतारोही न॑ चरम प॑ स्केल करलकै, लेकिन जेकरा स॑ मार्च आरू मई के महीना के बीच हजारों सपोर्ट स्टाफ क॑ बेस कैंप म॑ लानलऽ गेलै ।कन्चहा शेर्पा, दाहिना, काठमांडू, नेपाल, शनि, 2 मार्च, 2024 में अपन निवास पर एसोसिएटेड प्रेस के साथ एक साक्षात्कार स पहिने हुनकर बेटा त्सेरिंग शेर्पा द्वारा मदद भेटैत अछि.(एपी फोटो/निरंजन श्रेर्स्थ) जीबय वाला लोक के संख्या के बारे में चिंता भेल अछि. महीनो तक पहाड़ पर, कचरा आ कचरा पैदा करय वाला, मुदा अधिकारि के पास पर्वतारोही के लेल जे परमिट जारी करैत अछि ओकरा कटौती करय के कोनो योजना नहिं अछि.ऐन्हऽ नियम छै जेकरा म॑ पर्वतारोही क॑ अपनऽ कचरा, उपकरण आरू वू सब कुछ क॑ नीचें उतारना जरूरी छै या अपनऽ जमाव क॑ खोय के जोखिम उठाबै के जरूरत छै, लेकिन निगरानी बहुत प्रभावी नै रहलऽ छै ।“अखन बहुत गंदा अछि।लोक भोजन खएला के बाद टीन आ लपेटैत फेंकैत अछि।आब के उठाबय जा रहल अछि?”कंचा कहलक।“किछु पर्वतारोही बस अपनऽ कचरा क॑ क्रिवेस म॑ डंप करी दै छै, जे वू समय म॑ छिपलऽ छेलै लेकिन अंततः ई आधार कैंप म॑ नीचें बहतै, कैन्हेंकि बर्फ पिघलाय क॑ ओकरा नीचे के तरफ ले जाय छै।”शेर्पास के लेलऽ एवरेस्ट विश्व केरऽ कोमोलांग्मा या देवी माँ छै, आरू ओकरऽ समुदाय द्वारा पूज्य छै ।ई सब सामान्यतः शिखर पर चढ़ै सँ पहिने धार्मिक संस्कार करैत छथि |कंचा शेर्पा क॑ अपनऽ बेटा त्सेरिंग शेर्पा न॑ काठमांडू, नेपाल म॑ अपनऽ आवास प॑ एसोसिएटेड प्रेस के साथ साक्षात्कार स॑ पहल॑ 2 मार्च, 2024. (एपी फोटो/निरंजन श्रेष्ठ) “हुनी सब क॑ पहाड़ केरऽ गंदा नै करै के चाही ।ई हमरऽ सबस॑ बड़ऽ भगवान छै आरू ओकरा देवता सिनी क॑ गंदा नै करलऽ जाय,” हुनी कहलकै कि “कोमोलंगमा शेर्पास लेली सबस॑ बड़ऽ देवता छै लेकिन लोगऽ क॑ धूम्रपान करी क॑ मांस खाय क॑ पहाड़ प॑ फेंकलऽ जाय छै।”कंचा बस एकटा युवक छल जखन ओ हिलेरी-टेन्जिंग अभियान मे शामिल भ गेल छल।हिलेरी आरू टेनेजिंग के साथ-साथ एवरेस्ट के अंतिम शिविर में जाय वाला तीनों शेर्पा में शामिल छेलै।परमिट नहि रहला स आगू नहि जा सकल।ओ सब पहिने रेडियो पर सफल आरोहण के बारे में सुनलनि, आ फेर शिखर 2 में शिखर के जोड़ी के संग मिलल. “हम सब कैम्प 2 में जमा भेलहुं मुदा शराब नहिं छल ताहि लेल हम सब चाह आ जलपान के संग मना देलहुं,” ओ कहलनि.“हम तखन जे किछु क’ सकलहुँ से एकत्रित क’ ओकरा बेस कैम्प धरि पहुँचा देलहुँ।”बेस कैंप सं शिखर धरि जे मार्ग खोललनि से एखनो पर्वतारोही लोकनि करैत छथि.अस्थिर खुम्बू आइसफॉल के ऊपर बेस कैंप स॑ 1 तलक के खंड हर साल बदलै छै ।कंचा मे चारि टा बच्चा, आठ पोता आ 20 महीना के परपोती अछि।ओ माउंट एवरेस्ट केरऽ तलहटी में नामचे विलेज में परिवार के साथ रहै छै, जहां परिवार ट्रेकर्स आरू पर्वतारोही के पूरा करै वाला एगो छोटऽ होटल चलाबै छै ।

title: One in four tourists flying into Nepal in February was Indian - Firstpost
description: One in four tourists flying into Nepal in February was Indian  Firstpost
publisher.title: Firstpost
full_article:
Data released by the Nepal Tourism Board (NTB) shows that of the 97,426 tourists that entered the country last month via air travel, 25,578 came from India, followed by China with 9,180 and the US with 9,089 visitors

Though the data indicated that over 25,000 Indians visited Nepal in February, NTB Director Mani Lamichhane claims that the real figure is far higher because many Indian tourists traveled to the Himalayan nation by land Image Courtesy Agencies

According to the tourism authorities here on Saturday, India has become Nepal’s top inbound visitor market in February as the country’s vital industry progressively recovers from the coronavirus pandemic.

Data released by the Nepal Tourism Board (NTB) shows that of the 97,426 tourists that entered the country last month via air travel, 25,578 came from India, followed by China with 9,180 and the US with 9,089 visitors.

Advertisement

With 4,799 foreign visitors, Thailand comes in fourth on the list. The UK and Bangladesh come in fifth and sixth, with 4,099 and 4,571 visitors, respectively.

Though the data indicated that over 25,000 Indians visited Nepal in February, NTB Director Mani Lamichhane claims that the real figure is far higher because many Indian tourists traveled to the Himalayan nation by land.

Nepal saw 18,041 Indian tourists in January.

In February of this year, there were 33% more tourists arriving in Nepal by air than there were in February of 2023 (73,255 visitors). It was 95.12% recovery compared to 2019, the pre-Covid 19 timeframe. There were 1,02,423 tourists that arrived in Nepal in February 2019.

Advertisement

The COVID-19-affected tourist industry in Nepal is predicted to rebound in 2024, and the February data is encouraging, according to NTB Director Lamichhane.

According to him, the number of visitors would rise sharply starting in April since the travel season begins after March.

title: India emerges as Nepal's top inbound tourist market in Feb - Moneycontrol
description: India emerges as Nepal's top inbound tourist market in Feb  Moneycontrol
publisher.title: Moneycontrol
full_article:
The number of tourists arriving via air route in Nepal in February is 33 per cent up from February 2023, which witnessed arrival of 73,255 visitors.

India has emerged as Nepal's top inbound tourist market in February, the tourism authority here said on Saturday, as the key sector in the Himalayan nation is gradually witnessing recovery from the onslaught of the coronavirus pandemic.

Of the total 97,426 tourists arriving in the country by air route last month, 25,578 were from India, followed by China with 9,180 and the US with 9,089 visitors, according to data published by the Nepal Tourism Board (NTB).

Story continues below Advertisement Remove Ad

Thailand is in fourth place with 4,799 inbound visitors, while the UK and Bangladesh ranked fifth and sixth in the list with 4,571 and 4,099 tourists respectively.

According to NTB Director Mani Lamichhane, though the data showed over 25,000 Indians visiting Nepal in February, the actual number is much higher as a large number of tourists from India visited the country via land route.

In January, Nepal received 18,041 visitors from India.

The number of tourists arriving via air route in Nepal in February is 33 per cent up from February 2023, which witnessed arrival of 73,255 visitors. As compared to 2019, the pre-Covid 19 period, it was 95.12 per cent recovery. The number of tourists arrival in Nepal in February 2019 was 1,02,423, the NTB said.

Nepal's tourism sector, which is badly affected by COVID-19, is expected to revive in 2024, and the February data is a positive indication, NTB Director Lamichhane said.

As the tourism season starts after March, the number of visitors will significantly increase from next month, he said.

title: Mount Everest Climbers Must Now Meet This New Requirement - TIME
description: Mount Everest Climbers Must Now Meet This New Requirement  TIME
publisher.title: TIME
full_article:
Mount Everest climbers must now rent and wear a tracking device on their journeys to cut down time on search and rescue missions, CNN reported.

Rakesh Gurung, Nepal’s tourism department director, is quoted as telling the news outlet that a climber will pay $10 to $15 for a chip, which will be sewn into their jacket, then returned after the climb and rented to the next climber. Reputable mountaineering companies already use GPS trackers, according to Gurung.

TIME reached out to Nepal’s tourism department for further information.

This news comes ahead of the spring climbing season, which generally runs from March to May, when conditions are best to take on the world’s tallest mountain. Mountaineers must wait for the most favorable weather to summit the peak, with most ascents occurring around May 18, according to Outside magazine.

Mount Everest, always perilous to climb, has also become increasingly and dangerously crowded in recent years. Last year, Nepal issued a record number of permits to climb Mount Everest during the spring season, per the BBC. That season became one of the deadliest in recent memory, with 12 confirmed deaths and five climbers missing at the season’s close in June.

The government has taken other measures to attempt to keep climbers safe. Last year, Nepal’s Tourism Board announced that climbers on any mountain would be required to get a tracking information management system card from an authorized mountaineering agency in an effort to “ensure the safety and security of visitors” and discourage unlicensed treks.

Nepal also piloted tracking chips in the past. In 2017, the country’s tourism department provided some Everest climbers with GPS trackers to prevent false summit claims and make rescues easier, Reuters reported. At the time, tourism officials said that if the concept worked, they would make it mandatory for all climbers.

title: Nepal Proposes Five-Fold Increase in Airline Compensation for Passenger Injuries, Deaths - BNN Breaking
description: Nepal Proposes Five-Fold Increase in Airline Compensation for Passenger Injuries, Deaths  BNN Breaking
publisher.title: BNN Breaking
full_article:
Nepal's aviation sector is on the brink of a significant transformation with the introduction of a draft bill aimed at increasing compensation for passengers in the event of injury or death. The Civil Aviation Ministry has accelerated the process to enact separate air carriers' liability and insurance legislation for domestic flights, proposing a minimum compensation of $100,000, up from the current $20,000. This move comes years after Nepal adopted the Montreal Convention 1999, aligning domestic carrier obligations closer to international standards.

Advertisment

Reviving the Stalled Legislation

The draft bill, which has been in development since Nepal ratified the Montreal Convention in 2018, saw extensive discussions with stakeholders before being finalized in 2020. Despite this, it faced delays as successive tourism ministers failed to present it in Parliament, leaving it on hold without much explanation. Buddhi Sagar Lamichhane, a joint secretary at the ministry, confirmed the Cabinet's recent approval to prepare the bill, promising an expedited process for its passage.

Implications for Domestic Carriers

Advertisment

The proposed legislation significantly raises the stakes for Nepal's domestic airlines, requiring them to pay a minimum of $100,000 for passenger death or injury. This is a stark increase from the current $20,000 compensation cap. The draft bill also aligns with the Montreal Convention's standards for international flights, which demand carriers pay 128,821 Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) or approximately $171,018 if the carrier's negligence leads to passenger harm. However, the bill tailors these provisions to better fit Nepal's unique geographical and operational challenges, sparking debate among local carriers regarding feasibility, especially concerning delays.

Challenges and Delays

The frequent changes in ministry leadership and parliamentary prorogations have contributed to the bill's stagnation. The delay has had tangible consequences, notably for victims of the Yeti Airlines crash in Pokhara in January 2023, who were ineligible for the enhanced compensation. With over 900 fatalities from air crashes recorded since 1955, the draft bill's passage could mark a turning point in Nepal's commitment to aviation safety and passenger rights. Yet, it faces a critical period of reviews and approvals, expected to take at least two months, before it can become law.

The proposed increase in compensation for air crash victims represents a significant policy shift in Nepal's aviation sector, aiming to offer better protection for passengers while aligning domestic regulations with international standards. As the bill moves through the legislative process, its implications for airlines, passengers, and the broader aviation industry in Nepal will be closely watched.

title: CG Corp Global’s Nirvana Chaudhary talks expansion, wealth and uplifting Nepal - South China Morning Post
description: CG Corp Global’s Nirvana Chaudhary talks expansion, wealth and uplifting Nepal  South China Morning Post
publisher.title: South China Morning Post
full_article:
And right now, jobs are exactly what the young people of Nepal need, as they continue to leave the country in their droves in search of a better life – hurting both the economy and society, Chaudhary says.

The Chaudhary Group conglomerate he heads not only contributes more in tax revenues than any other company in the country and accounts for approaching 10 per cent of the economy, it is also one of the South Asian nation’s biggest employers.

Nirvana Chaudhary, the eldest son of Nepal ’s only billionaire Binod Chaudhary, doesn’t just want to aggressively grow the family business, he says he needs to.

Asia’s richest families are set to hand down US$2.5 trillion in intergenerational wealth by 2030, creating a new generation of crazy rich Asians. Read the main story here , the profile on Indonesian billionaire Sukanto Tanoto’s daughter Belinda here , on Mamee’s Pierre Pang here , and on Lippo Group’s John Riady here

According to local media, employment and education are the main reasons for the exodus. Chaudhary says a recent political reshuffle also contributed.

“So we need to multiply jobs, multiply our growth, create more industries,” he said, adding that he “wasn’t going anywhere”.

The 41-year-old, who is based in Nepal with his wife and two children, leads the Chaudhary Group as its managing director, with direct control over 11 of the conglomerate’s businesses while his two younger brothers manage the others.

The family’s business interests span banks, hotels, factories and industrial estates, as well as the popular Wai Wai brand of instant noodles.

Chaudhary told This Week in Asia that his dream is to “create small universes under a big universe”, vertically integrating the family’s businesses to eventually create a one-stop shop for customers.

The Kathmandu Valley. The Chaudhary Group’s business interests span banks, hotels, factories and industrial estates in the mountainous Himalayan nation. Photo: Getty Images

But he says he wants to expand the Chaudhary Group in a measured and disciplined way. For starters, he is bound by governance rules set by the group’s family-run investment council, as well as “standard operating procedures” for everything he does with the business.

There is also a professional wealth management team that advises the family on a regular basis.

“Maybe 10 years ago, we used to ‘catch’ any business that came our way, not any more. Today we have established core competences in FMCG [fast-moving consumer goods], hotels, financial services, and by 2027, [according to our mandates] we will be in FMCG, energy, infrastructure and telecoms,” he said.

My country is so poor … That is why I’ve decided that I want to grow and generate large amounts of wealth, so that I can give back to our society Nirvana Chaudhary, CG Corp Global managing director

“People [also] say as a Nepali company, we are investing more outside [the country], but that’s not true; 80 per cent of our investments are in Nepal.”

Concerns have been raised about the family’s tax compliance after its members were implicated in the Pandora Papers leak of 2021, a sequel to the earlier Panama Papers investigation into tax havens and money laundering.

Binod Chaudhary was among 19 Nepalis found to have set up companies in tax havens such as the British Virgin Islands. The Chaudharys say these investments complied with the law.

Nirvana Chaudhary says he only wants to do right by Nepal’s society, a desire that was cemented by the devastating 7.8-magnitude earthquake that hit the country in 2015

“Three hours [after the earthquake], we opened up our schools and colleges as relief camps. And because we have the largest healthcare company, we were able to provide free medical aid to people,” he said. “That year, my purpose changed.

“My country is so poor, and I don’t feel good being the only billionaire [family] in the country. That is why I’ve decided that I want to grow and generate large amounts of wealth, so that I can give back to our society.”

The family has its own philanthropic arm, the Chaudhary Foundation, which focuses on areas such as education, disaster management and healthcare, especially for children, under the motto to “uplift Nepal so that every citizen can aspire to live a safe, healthy and productive life”.

Trekking to Everest Base Camp in Nepal. Nirvana Chaudhary completed the arduous trek in 2015. Photo: Getty Images

Nirvana Chaudhary is vice-chair of the foundation, while his father is chairman.

“It’s a family collective vision to do more in philanthropy to give more back,” he said. “My father told us that you might have the best room in a boat but if that boat is sinking, what’s the point of having that room?”

The Nepali businessman likes to show his love for his mountainous homeland in other ways as well. In 2015, he completed the arduous trek to the base of Mount Everest, the world’s highest mountain that straddles Nepal’s border with China.

full_article:
Bhutan, hailed as the last Buddhist kingdom on Earth, and Nepal, renowned as the land of Mount Everest, boast unique charms that beckon travellers to explore them. However, when faced with the question of Nepal vs Bhutan – which destination to explore first — many find themselves pondering.

To address this question, we have done all the research to help you decide which destination, Nepal or Bhutan, aligns better with your preferences. These beautiful, mountainous, and green countries promise an escape like no other from the daily hustle and bustle amidst their majestic natural landscapes.

Best time to visit Bhutan vs Nepal

Due to their geographical location in the Himalayan mountain ranges, Bhutan and Nepal share similar climates and weather patterns. Both countries experience the usual spring, summer, autumn and winter, with occasional rain and snowfall that contribute to cooling temperatures.

Bhutan: The best time to visit Bhutan is during spring or autumn. From March to April, Bhutan’s landscape bursts into vibrant colours as the red silk cotton trees and rhododendrons bloom across the land. As autumn approaches in October and November, Bhutan transitions into a different spectacle as leaves start falling, offering a unique perspective on its lush landscapes. Additionally, Spring and Autumn host various festivals like Thimphu Tsechu and Paro Tsechu, providing an excellent opportunity to experience Bhutanese culture.

Nepal: For the best experience of Nepal’s natural beauty, plan your visit during spring or autumn. October and November mark the trekking season, welcoming adventure enthusiasts to explore the wonders of the land on foot amidst the picturesque landscapes of Autumn. Spring, too, is the best time to visit, as rhododendron forests are in full bloom, and wildlife sightings are frequent in national parks due to migratory patterns.

Exploring the Himalayan nature and landscapes

Bhutan and Nepal, both landlocked countries set across the Himalayan mountain ranges, offer breathtaking landscapes, diverse wildlife, and abundant greenery. Here’s what sets them apart:

Bhutan: Hidden away in the Eastern Himalayas, Bhutan boasts dramatic landscapes featuring valleys, mountains and plains. With over 72 percent of its land covered in forests and seven percent adorned with perpetual snow and glaciers, Bhutan is a haven of lush greenery. The nation is home to Gangkhar Puensum, the highest unclimbed mountain in the world, serving as the highest peak in Bhutan. Explore natural treasures at Royal Manas National Park, Jigme Dorji National Park and Bumdeling Wildlife Sanctuary.

Nepal: Another famous landlocked country in Asia, Nepal is defined by its mountainous terrain, including the majestic Mount Everest, the world’s highest peak. Nepal boasts several notable peaks, attracting mountain climbers from around the world. The southern region, known as the Terai, features fertile and lush lowlands. Experience the exciting wonders of Nepal’s nature at Chitwan National Park, Shivapuri Nagarjun National Park, Sagarmatha National Park, Annapurna Conservation Area and Bardia National Park.

Best places to visit in Bhutan and Nepal

Discovering the cities and valleys of Bhutan and Nepal promises a journey filled with surprises. Before planning your trip, explore the must-visit destinations in both countries.

Bhutan: Experience the rich culture and lifestyle of Bhutan by exploring Thimphu, Paro, Punakha, Trongsa, Phuentsholing, Phobjikha Valley, Bumthang Valley and Haa Valley.

Nepal: Dive into the culture, traditions, and hospitality of Nepal in Kathmandu, Pokhara, Nagarkot, Patan, Bhaktapur, Lumbini and Janakpur. For more insights, refer to our detailed guide on the best places to visit in Nepal.

Best things to do in Bhutan vs Nepal

It will be a journey filled with unique experiences in Bhutan and Nepal, both featuring adventures in the wild and encounters with ancient traditions. Here’s the breakdown of the activities you can enjoy in both countries.

Bhutan: Immerse yourself in Bhutanese culture by attending traditional festivals (tsechus) in the dzongs, like Thimphu Tsechu and Paro Tsechu. Embrace the culture further by dressing in traditional attire: gho for men and kira for women. Hike to the famous Tiger’s Nest Monastery (Paro Taktsang) or trek the ancient Trans Bhutan Trail. For adventure seekers, try the Jhomolhari Base Camp trek, engage in traditional archery, go rafting in Puna Tsang Chhu, Wang Chhu and Sankosh River, or experience camping in the wild.

Nepal: Challenge yourself with a climb to Mount Everest or try your luck at the famed Everest Base Camp Trek and Annapurna Circuit. Explore the mythological sites of Lumbini and Janakpur, the birthplaces of Gautam Buddha and Sita from the Ramayana. Enjoy mountain biking and paragliding in Pokhara, or experience river rafting in the Trisuli River. Immerse yourself in unique festivals like Kukur Tihar and Indra Jatra. Witness wildlife, including one-horned rhinoceros and tigers, in their natural habitat.

Best hotels in Bhutan and Nepal

Both countries offer a diverse range of accommodations, from homestays to luxury mountain retreats, providing travellers with wholesome and rejuvenating stays unlike any other.

Bhutan: While several homes across Bhutan offer stays for travellers seeking insight into the local lifestyle and culture, those desiring luxury can opt for renowned establishments such as Le Meridien Paro Riverfront, Amankora Paro, Pemako and The Postcard Dewa in Thimphu.

Nepal: Nepal boasts a range of earthy guesthouses that offer a window into the Nepalese lifestyle. Additionally, there are luxury hotels and resorts offering unparalleled comfort. Noteworthy accommodations in Nepal include Hotel Yak & Yeti, The Terraces Resort and Spa, Hyatt Regency and Dusit Princess in Kathmandu Valley, The Pavilions Himalayas in Pokhara, Dorje’s Resort & Spa and Dwarika’s Resort in Dhulikhel, along with Meghauli Sarai, A Taj Safari, and Kasara in Chitwan National Park.

Shopping guide: What to buy in Nepal vs Bhutan

Bhutan: Make the most of your shopping spree in Bhutan by collecting Thangka paintings, Bhutanese stamps, Yatha bags, carved masks, Desh paper products, Dzi beads, honey, traditional outfits, datshi (cheese) and local jewellery.

Nepal: Preserve your travel memories of Nepal with souvenirs such as Nepali tea, yak cheese, yak butter, Lokta paper products, organic coffee beans, handmade local jewellery, wooden products and more.

Comparing the culinary offerings

No vacation is complete without sampling the local food, and both Nepal and Bhutan offer unique cuisines that reflect their nature, culture and people. Here’s a breakdown of what Nepalese and Bhutanese cuisines have to offer.

Bhutan: Indulge in Bhutanese delicacies such as ema datshi, kewa datshi, jasha maroo, phaksha paro, shamu datshi, puta, hoentay, gondo datshi and Bhutanese red rice.

For an authentic culinary experience in Thimphu, visit Folk Heritage Museum Restaurant, Babesa Village Restaurant, Zombala 2 Restaurant, or Bhutan Kitchen. In Paro, My Kind Of Place, Soechey Restaurant, Sonam Trophel Restaurant and Bukhari Restaurant are highly recommended.

Nepal: Enjoy a variety of Nepalese dishes including momos, gundruk, dal bhat, sel roti, choila, thukpa, chataamari, yomari, phuchka, khasi ko masu and juju dhau.

In the Kathmandu Valley, try the local fare at Shree Trishakti Newari Restaurant, Almond’s Cafe & Restaurant, Chatamari Chen, and The Village Cafe. In Pokhara, dine at Moondance Restaurant, Momotarou and Mo2’s Delights.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

– What are the main differences between Nepal and Bhutan as travel destinations?

The main differences between Nepal and Bhutan as travel destinations lie in their culture, people, and landscapes.

– Which country, Nepal or Bhutan, is easier for tourists to travel to?

Nepal is generally considered easier and more budget-friendly for tourists to travel to as it has been a popular travel destination for a longer time, whereas Bhutan opened its doors to tourists in 1974.

– Which country offers better trekking opportunities, Nepal or Bhutan?

Nepal is renowned for its trekking, hiking, and climbing opportunities, especially with iconic destinations like Mount Everest and the Annapurna Circuit. However, Bhutan also has significant potential for trekking, boasting the world’s highest unclimbed mountain, Gangkhar Puensum.

– Which country, Nepal or Bhutan, offers better opportunities for wildlife viewing?

Both Nepal and Bhutan offer excellent opportunities for wildlife viewing, as they are home to diverse ecosystems and a wide range of animal species.

– Which country is more suitable for adventure activities like rafting and paragliding, Nepal or Bhutan?

Both Nepal and Bhutan offer exciting adventure activities such as river rafting, camping, and paragliding, making them equally suitable for adventure enthusiasts.

– Which country, Nepal vs Bhutan, is less crowded and offers a more peaceful travel experience?

Bhutan is generally less crowded than Nepal, offering travellers a more peaceful and serene travel experience.

ट्रेकिंग के अवसर प्रदान करै छै, नेपाल या भूटान ?नेपाल अपनऽ ट्रेकिंग, हाइकिंग, आरू पर्वतारोहण के अवसर लेली प्रसिद्ध छै, खास करी क॑ माउंट एवरेस्ट आरू अन्नपूर्णा सर्किट जैसनऽ प्रतिष्ठित गंतव्यऽ के साथ ।लेकिन भूटान म॑ ट्रेकिंग केरऽ महत्वपूर्ण संभावना भी छै, जेकरा म॑ दुनिया केरऽ सबस॑ ऊंचऽ अगणित पहाड़ गैंगखर प्यून्सम केरऽ घमंड करलऽ गेलऽ छै ।– कोन देश नेपाल या भूटान, वन्यजीव देखबाक लेल नीक अवसर प्रदान करैत अछि ?नेपाल आरू भूटान दोनों वन्यजीव देखै लेली उत्कृष्ट अवसर प्रदान करै छै, कैन्हेंकि ई विविध पारिस्थितिकी तंत्र आरू पशु प्रजाति के एक विस्तृत श्रृंखला के घर छै ।– राफ्टिंग आरू पैराग्लाइडिंग, नेपाल या भूटान जैसनऽ रोमांच गतिविधि लेली कोन देश अधिक उपयुक्त छै ?नेपाल आरू भूटान दोनों नदी राफ्टिंग, कैम्पिंग, आरू पैराग्लाइडिंग जैसनऽ रोमांचक रोमांच गतिविधियऽ के प्रस्ताव दै छै, जेकरा स॑ ई सब रोमांच के शौकीन लोगऽ लेली समान रूप स॑ उपयुक्त होय जाय छै ।– कोन देश नेपाल बनाम भूटान में भीड़ कम छै आ यात्रा के अनुभव बेसी शांतिपूर्ण छै ?भूटान सामान्यतया नेपाल सं कम भीड़ छै, जे यात्री सब के एकटा बेसी शांतिपूर्ण आ शांत यात्रा के अनुभव के पेशकश करै छै.द्वारा लिखित

title: Nepal-Pakistan Friendship Cricket Tournament 2024 kicks off - Myrepublica
description: Nepal-Pakistan Friendship Cricket Tournament 2024 kicks off  Myrepublica
publisher.title: Myrepublica
full_article:
KATHMANDU, March 3: The "9th Edition of Nepal-Pakistan Friendship T20 Cricket Tournament-2024" kicked off today with a joint inauguration by Ambassador of Pakistan Abrar Hussain Hashmi, Binaya Raj Pandey, former President of Cricket Association of Nepal (CAN), and Ujjal Raj Bhandary, Deputy CEO of Himalayan Bank Limited.

During the ceremony, Pandey and Bhandary commended the Embassy for organizing the event annually since 2014 and emphasized the potential of cricket and sports to unite the youth of both nations and acknowledged Pakistan's efforts in promoting sports and education for fostering healthy activities among young people.

Ambassador Hashmi highlighted cricket as more than just a sport, emphasizing its role in bringing people together and building camaraderie and teamwork. He expressed confidence that the event would strengthen the friendly relations between Nepal and Pakistan, particularly among the youth.

Twelve cricket teams are participating in this year's nine-day tournament, scheduled to conclude on 10th March 2024. The event will be live-streamed on the Nepali channel "Mithila Nepal TV."

title: Hong Kong's men set for tough T20 test against Nepal, Papua New Guinea - South China Morning Post
description: Hong Kong's men set for tough T20 test against Nepal, Papua New Guinea  South China Morning Post
publisher.title: South China Morning Post
full_article:
Simon Willis’ side go into the competition having beaten Qatar on Friday in the super over of the decider of their three-match T20 series in Doha.

The tri-series at Tin Kwong Road Recreation Ground comes on the back of a one-day tournament involving Malaysia and Canada, and the East Asia Cup against China and Japan.

Hong Kong’s cricketers face another stern test over the next 10 days, with a series of T20 internationals against Nepal and Papua New Guinea.

Nepal, meanwhile, are in the middle of a T20 competition of their own at home, where they are hosting Namibia and the Netherlands.

PNG are returning to the city for the first time since the South China Cup and West Pacific Cup in 2018.

The tournament will begin with Hong Kong taking on Nepal on Saturday for the Hong Kong Men’s T20I Series Friendship Cup, which officials said was “a one off match to celebrate the relationship” between the two cricket associations.

After that, the three teams will play a round-robin tournament, starting on Sunday and running through until March 13.

“We are delighted to welcome the Cricket Association of Nepal and Cricket PNG to visit Hong Kong for the upcoming Hong Kong Men’s T20I Series 2024,” Burji Shroff, the chairman of Cricket Hong Kong, China, said.

“We hope this tournament can showcase the development of cricket in Hong Kong and hopefully our fans will enjoy the exciting clashes between Hong Kong and the visiting teams.”

Fixtures (all games Tin Kwong Road Recreation Ground): Saturday, March 9: Hong Kong v Nepal, 1.30pm. Sunday, March 10: Hong Kong v Nepal, 1.30pm. Tuesday, March 12: PNG v Nepal, 9am; Hong Kong v PNG, 2pm. Wednesday, March 13: third place v Hong Kong A, 9am; Final, 2pm.
